newsitem.title: USA: NY Pataki says childcare funding will rise $86 mln.
newsitem.headline: NY Pataki says childcare funding will rise $86 mln.

text.p: New York State Gov. George Pataki on Wednesday said that the state, which helps pay the costs of child care for about 100,000 children, will get more than $86 million in extra Federal aid over the next 18 months.

New York expects to spend a total of $312.6 million, including almost $154 million of federal money and state and local contributions, to pay for child care for welfare recipients and low-income families during 1996-97.
New York could draw an extra $26.5 million during that fiscal year, which ends on March 31, and obtain another $60.2 million in the 1997-98 fiscal year.
By March 1998, New York anticipates that it will have $400 million to spend on child care, a 20 percent increase, which includes about $241 million in federal money.
Pataki said increasing funding for child care programs should help the state continue to shift people from welfare to work.
"It will also help keep people who may be at risk of going on welfare off the rolls and help them remain independent."
About 60,000 low-income families benefit from the child care program.
